ygData.subject: Re: negative_A reaction option returning nan
ygData.msgSnippet: Really what it comes down to, as far as I understand, is the fact that all of these reaction rate coefficients (A, n, Ea) are all just best-fit parameters.

Subject: Re: negative_A reaction option returning nan

Really what it comes down to, as far as I understand, is the fact that
all =
of these reaction rate coefficients (A, n, Ea) are all just
best-fit parame=
ters.  The way that this particular reaction was put
together, was to have =
the rate of this single reaction be a
combination of two identical reaction=
s with different rates:

NH+NO=3DN2O+H    2.94E+14  -0.40   0.000E+00
NH+NO=
=3DN2O+H    -2.16E+13  -0.23   0.000E+00

So, the actual overall forward ra=
te of reaction is (where both are
based on zero activation energy):

rate_f=
=3D (2.94E+14)*T^(-0.40)*[NH][NO] + (-2.16E+13)*T^(-0.23)*[NH][NO]

which s=
implifies to:

rate_f=3D (2.94E+14*T^(-0.40) - 2.16E+13*T^(-0.23))*[NH][NO]=


where the "new overall" kf is:

kf=3D 2.94E+14*T^(-0.40) - 2.16E+13*T^(-0=
.23)

which should turn out to be a positive number every time in order to
=
keep the thermodynamics consistent (emphasis on should).  Then, then
reacti=
on rate coefficient for the reverse reaction (kr) can be
calculated in the =
typical way with Keq.  Hope all this helps more than
it confuses. :)

Dan

=
--- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, "andr_1976" <andr1976@...> wrote:
>
> Dear =
Dan 
> 
> I'm not really sure that I understand the concept of a negative
>=
 prefactor, however this might be a fix:
> A negative prefactor should resu=
lt in a a negative rate constant.
> According to the principle of microscop=
ic reversiblility 
> 
> k_b =3D k_f/K_eq 
> 
> , where K_eq is the equilibi=
rum constant for an elementary reaction
> step and k_f and k_b are the forw=
ard and backward rate constants,
> respectively. Since K_eq can not be nega=
vtive (at least from my
> knowledge of basic statistical thermodynamics) a =
negative k_a would
> result in k_b being negative as well. For a simple rea=
ction, say,
> 
> a + b =3D c
> 
> the rate equation is:
> 
> r =3D k_f *[a]=
*[b] - k_b[c]
> 
> Changing the sign of both k_f and k_b 
> 
> r =3D -k_f *=
[a]*[b] + k_b*[c]
> 
> This is actually equal to the rate equation of the r=
everse reaction.
> Thus, in my point of view a negative prefactor is just a=
 "cover up" of
> the fact that the reaction was written up in the wrong dir=
ection. 
> Does this make any sense, or have I completely missed the point =
here?
> 
> Kind regards
> 
> Anders   
>
